question: From the histogram of the data above, estimate the left edge of a symmetric 80% confidence interval.

answers.feedback: Correct. From the figure, the cumulative histogram has approximately 90% of its relative frequency above 80, which means 10% is less than this value. The 10% percentile value is approximately 81.5.
Incorrect. We are looking for the left edge of the 80% CI in this problem.
Incorrect. Did you look at 0.2 on the $y$-axis? Remember that for a symmetric 80% CI, the CI will exclude 10% of the observed values on each edge, not 20%.

question: From the histogram of the data above, estimate the right edge of a symmetric 80% confidence interval.

answers.feedback: Correct. From the figure, the cumulative histogram has approximately 90% of its relative frequency below 330, which means 10% is above this value. The 90% percentile value is approximately 328.7
Incorrect. We are looking for the right edge of the 80% CI in this problem.
Incorrect. Did you look at 0.8 on the $y$-axis? Remember that for a symmetric 80% CI, the CI will exclude 10% of the observed values on each edge, not 20%.

question: From the histogram of the data above, estimate the left edge of a symmetric 90% confidence interval.

answers.feedback: Correct. From the figure, the cumulative histogram has approximately 95% of its relative frequency above 0. The 5% percentile for this data set is actually (approximately) 23.34.
Incorrect. We are looking for the left edge of the 80% CI in this problem.
Incorrect. Did you look at 0.1 on the $y$-axis? Remember that for a symmetric 90% CI, the CI will exclude 5% of the observed values on each edge, not 10%.

question: From the histogram of the data above, estimate the right edge of a symmetric 90% confidence interval.

answers.feedback: Correct. From the figure, the cumulative histogram has approximately 95% of its relative frequency below 360, which means 5 is above this value. The 95% percentile value is approximately 358.5
Incorrect. Did you look at 0.9 on the $y$-axis? Remember that for a symmetric 90% CI, the CI will exclude 5% of the observed values on each edge, not 10%.
Incorrect. We are looking for the right edge of the 80% CI in this problem.
